subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Keyboard mappings and keyboard layouts
msgSnippet: I d guess all those who can t afford a color laser printer but have to settle for a black and white one. Given the volume of color to black and white printing
messageBody:
I'd guess all those who can't afford a color laser printer
but have to settle for a black and white one. Given the
volume of color to black and white printing I do an inkjet
color printer wouldn't be cost efficient either, since color
cartridges dry up after a certain time whether you use them
or not. I might be atypical, though, since I print a lot of
text documents in my work.

/BP

{Yd ges ol DOz hV kant afQrd u kolur lEZur PriNtur/PrinFcr
bt hv t setcl f u blaknWYt Mun. givN D volyUm v kolur t
blaknWYt PriNtG/PrinFG Y d un iGkjet kolur PriNtur/PrinFcr
wdNt b kost efiScNt IDur, sins kolur kArtrijZ drY cp aftur u
surtun tYm WeDur y yUZ Dm Qr not. Y mYt b atipikl, DO, sins
Y PriNt/PrinF u lot v teXt dokyUmunts iN mY Murk.

/bIpI}

Moira O'Brien skrev:
> This is true - but how many people only ever print in
> black & white these days?
>
> mQra
>
>
>
> On 08/01/2008, Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...>
> wrote:
>> On 8.1.2008 Moira O'Brien wrote:
>>> Can I suggest though that you use colour to identify the
>>> disputed letters - eg red for disagreements and pale
>>> orange for substantial agreement. This will make it much
>>> easier to read.
>>>
>> The snag with color coding is that it goes away in a
black-and-
>> white printout, unless the colors are chosen to give
>> different shades of gray.
>>
>> {D sNag wi kolur kOdG z Dt i gOz uwE iN u blak n WYt
>> priNtUt, cNles D kolurZ r COzN t giv difreNt SERZ/SEdz
>> v grE.}
>>
>> /BP 8^)>
>> --
>> Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
>> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>> No man forgets his original trade: the rights of
>> nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar,
>> if grammarians discuss them. -Dr. Samuel Johnson (1707
>> - 1784)
>>
>>
>
>
>
